snippet: Some abortion opponents say emergency contraception pills may block fertilized eggs from implanting, but scientists say there is no evidence the pills work that way.
abstract: Political debate over morning-after pills and abortion, a divisive election-year issue, is probably rooted in outdated or incorrect scientific guesses about how the pills work; studies, which support fact that pills delay ovulation, have not established that emergency contraceptive pills prevent fertilized eggs from implanting in the womb, an outcome that many abortion opponents consider the same as abortion (Series: Political Science).
lead_paragraph: Some abortion opponents say emergency contraception pills may block fertilized eggs from implanting, but scientists say there is no evidence the pills work that way.

headline.print_headline: No Abortion Role Seen for Morning-After Pill
headline.seo: Science at Issue in Debate on Morning-After Pill
headline.main: Abortion Qualms on Morning-After Pill May Be Unfounded
